RT @RCNWales: In December 2021 the @WelshGovernment announced an extra 1.3bn for NHS Wales, while @WalesGovernance estimated ¬£505m of Covid‚Ä¶

If only it was that easy to just say 'no'.
Try saying no to the patient who has urgent need of personal care at half past 7 or the family member who has turned up at this time or called on the phone for an update 
Or Prinicple E-if it wasn't written down it never happened. https://t.co/z4JYwRp2oQ

@theRCN @vavel7 Often we are physically unable to leave due to staff not turning up on time, or even at all for the next shift.  Or due to the site manager ringing and reallocating staff and the ensuing arguments between staff refusing to go and those who want to just go home.
RT @vavel7: Calling nursing staff in a study testing the usefulness of an online psychological skills training programme  #Nursing #NurseTw‚Ä¶

This reminder of where I was 3 years ago is not something I am proud of anymore. I put my uniform on and my husband says I come out of the bathroom like Superman. I am not.I am Clark Kent. This week I applied to work in our local supermarket. Anything has to be better than this.

The #Conservative government has its knees on the neck of the #HealthService and locally the #Labour run #WelshAssembly is kicking it in the ribs. Neither party has invested in the health and social care sector in a meaningful way (11)

The constant financial hardship, the gruelling 12.5 hr shifts with at least 2 hours wrap around travelling. The late nights studying. The joy of graduation.  Feeling you were a part of something which could make a change for the better. The #NHS is on its knees(10)

The profession that meant I didn't see my children for days at a time, the one I gave so much to, and yet took more in return. The training that meant whilst I was lucky to have a Welsh bursary, the local council saw it as a wage and took it back off us (9)

I go into work knowing this could and probably will, happen again. Dealing with families who are outraged by the standards of care we are giving (or not giving). My biggest fear is a family member being admitted to the hospital I work in (8)

This week I have been physically and verbally abused multiple times. Nothing will be done. The patients who did this will be here for months to come,having been here for months already, as the social care system is overwhelmed (7)

And the good will of exhausted staff. I am still waving red flags. Nothing is happening. Nothing is getting better. I look at this pin and think this has been 3 years of hell with no anticipation of improvement (6)

And it is even worse than during the pandemic. The staffing is criminally short. The danger which patients are in is appalling. The weariness and exhaustion is transparent on  ALL the staff. The exodus is real. The hospital is held together with duct tape(not a joke ) (5)

I had a breakdown and left. I tried something else and it was worse (working for the #DWP as a functional assessor was just as bad, another failing system). Now I am an #AgencyNurse in the same hospital I started in (4)

By colleagues 'Yeah it's really hard we have a high turnover of staff because not everyone can hack it.'
Then #COVID19 hit.
The world went to hell.
2 years into my 'dream career' I was having panic attacks at work.Crying daily. Dreaming about work(when I could get to sleep) (3)

I was idealistic and empowered by the education that I had fought hard for and raised red flag after red flag to be told by my manager 'this is nursing, get used to it.' By Occ Health 'have you considered a different career?' (2)

A üßµ.I graduated 3 years ago from @cardiffuni with a first in Adult Nursing. A journey which had been 8 years in the making.
First #NQN job on a 'surgical' ward. It wasn't.  It was the dumping ground for the rest of the hospital (1) https://t.co/GWMdIs75rG

You realise super quickly that the reason you work the same places over and over is because they see agency as disposable without ever looking at the underlying cause of #NurseShortages
Staff feel unsupported and undervalued in a system that sees replaceable when they  burnout

So....I opened my mouth,probably shot myself in the foot for being hired there again but at least I raised my voice.
Aren't we supposed to advocate for those who cannot advocate for themselves?
And 'it is what it is' has to be the most damaging phrase in #Nursing (2)

Proper falling down moment yesterday...
A patient's relative said 'you are an agency nurse, why did you chose to come back here this ward is so awful.'
They have no faith their loved ones are being cared for (1)

@DapperDan That is so so wonderful! Thank you for sharing this beautiful moment

For my daughter. For my family, for the 800+ other children waiting for the Neurodevelopmental team at @SwanseabayNHS to assess them. 
We are systematically failing our daughters. And told there is nothing we can do to make things better. It's not acceptable.

Add to that a postcode which identifies us as living in social housing, and on top of being a loud woman who will stand up and shout for the rights of her children, and you stand next to no chance of being labelled an apologist for shitty parenting.
I am so very very angry.

Because even the most basic research shows that #Autism in girls presents differently. Girls voices are not listened to. We women and mothers are shouting into an abyss. We are told we are too over protective, too anxious, too much and to pipe down.
By that time, she, and us as a family, will have been looked over, looked down upon and disregarded by primary school teachers, secondary school teachers, the SEN department, health visitors....

It has taken 4 years of yelling to get to the point where we have been listened to about our daughter's #ASD symptoms. Our reward for this is a letter confirming our suspicions, and joining a 2 year waiting list before the official assessment can begin.
She will be 16.
